history.content:
You need Xcode for iOS, which I believe is only available on Macs (although if you have a PC you could try to do a virtual machine thing??).  Here's Apple's official documentation on Swift 3.  I'd say just look up some tutorials before you start building your app, Xcode can be super intimidating at first with all the options.   I'm currently taking the iOS Decal, so here's a link to their website for some resources too!  Best of luck!

Make sure you have a good computer, xcode tends to crash a lot, and if your computer can't handle it the whole process will be a pain. If you want to put your final app in the App Store, make sure to purchase an Apple Developer Account. I did this last summer, from my experience, there are some things that will go wrong that you won't really be able to fix by just looking at the Decal resources as I assume your project will deviate from what they do. You will just have to end up using google to find ways to fix things when they do go wrong. You will need to use swift or objective c depending on what exactly you want to do. I only used Swift, it's fairly similar to Python, so it should be pretty easy to get the basics down. Not so sure about objective c. Good Luck!

You need Xcode for iOS, which I believe is only available on Macs (although if you have a PC you could try to do a virtual machine thing??).  Here's Apple's official documentation on Swift 3.  I'd say just look up some tutorials before you start building your app, Xcode can be super intimidating at first with all the options.   I'm currently taking the iOS Decal, so here's a link to their website for some resources too!  Best of luck!

children.subject: The IOS Decal generally share all their final products to Prof Garcia on the last day of class, I really recommend attending.  They share what the did and show it actually working on a big screen.  it's super cool and inspiring.  Looks like it would be on April 25th according to their calendar.

history.content:
Hi, I'm currently a junior majoring in CS and I've never really done a side project, and I'd like to make some type of iOS app for fun during the summer. I have never really done CS outside of coursework and technical internships, so I am pretty lost on how to get started on building that? What materials would I need (swift, xcode, etc.) and general pointers to get started?

Any help would be greatly appreciated thank you!
history.subject: Some pointers on working on a side project (iOS app)?
